title: PSY360: Research Methods
text:
Preface
Welcome to PSY360: Research Methods! The goal of this course is to introduce you to the world of research and discuss how research is conducted, why research is conducted, and what it means to conduct research.

Chapter 1: Introduction to Research Methods and Statistics


Chapter 2: Variables, Measurement, and Scales of Measurement


Chapter 3: Probability and Probability Distributions


Chapter 4: Sampling and Sampling Distributions


Chapter 5: Hypothesis Testing and Estimation


Chapter 6: One-Sample t-tests and Confidence Intervals


Chapter 7: Independent Samples t-tests and Confidence Intervals


Chapter 8: One-Way ANOVA


Chapter 9: Two-Way ANOVA


Chapter 10: Correlation and Regression


Chapter 11: Logistic Regression and Multiple Regression


Chapter 12: Non-Parametric Tests


Chapter 13: Factor Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling


Chapter 14: Meta-Analysis


Chapter 15: Advanced Topics in Research Methods and Statistics

See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.

title: 2  Let’s Take a Sentence
text:
library(stringr)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(janeaustenr)
library(ggplot2)
library(wesanderson)
library(tidyr)

sent <- sample(sentences,1)

sent

[1] "Mud was spattered on the front of his white shirt."



2.0.1 How many characters?

str_length(sent)

[1] 50




2.0.2 How many words?

length(unlist(str_match_all(sent, "\\b\\w+\\b")))

[1] 10




2.0.3 How many words start with a vowel?

sent_split <- unlist(str_split(sent, boundary(type = "word")))

str_extract(sent_split, "^[aeiou]\\w+" )

 [1] NA   NA   NA   "on" NA   NA   "of" NA   NA   NA  




2.0.4 How many words start with a consonant?

sent_split <- unlist(str_split(sent, boundary(type = "word")))
# We only need to change one character!
str_extract(sent_split, "[^aeiou]\\w+" )

 [1] "Mud"       "was"       "spattered" NA          "the"       "front"    
 [7] NA          "his"       "white"     "shirt"    



# Messing around
book_name <- 
  austen_books() |> 
  select(book) |> 
  unique() |> 
  pull()

# Assign page length
bk <- 
  tibble(
    book = book_name,
    page = runif(length(book),250,400) |> round(0),
    title = page/2
    ) 
bk |> 
  ggplot(aes(book,page, fill = book, label = book)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity",
           show.legend = FALSE) +
  theme_void() +
  geom_text(angle = 90,
            aes(y = title)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = wes_palette(8, 
                                         name = "Zissou1", 
                                         type = "continuous"))





# Basic
bk |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = book,y = page)) + 
  geom_point(size = 8) +  
  geom_segment(aes(x = book, xend = book, y = 0, yend = page)) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(y = "\nPage Length") 





# Weird Thing

dat <- 
  data.frame(
  season = rep(1:4,each = 10),
  episode = rep(1:10, 4),
  rating = runif(40,6.5,9.2) |> round(2)
) |> 
  arrange(season, episode) |> 
  mutate(episode_id = row_number()) |> 
  group_by(season) |> 
  mutate(
    avg = mean(rating),
    episode_mod = episode_id + (4 * season),
    mid = mean(episode_mod)
  ) |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  mutate(season = factor(season))

dat_lines <-
  dat %>% 
  group_by(season) %>% 
  summarize(
    start_x = min(episode_mod) - 5,
    end_x = max(episode_mod) + 5,
    y = unique(avg)
  ) %>% 
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(start_x, end_x),
    names_to = "type",
    values_to = "x"
  ) %>% 
  mutate(
    x_group = if_else(type == "start_x", x + .1, x - .1),
    x_group = if_else(type == "start_x" & x == min(x), x_group - .1, x_group),
    x_group = if_else(type == "end_x" & x == max(x), x_group + .1, x_group)
  )

theme_set(theme_minimal())
theme_update(
  plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#fafaf5", color = "#fafaf5"),
  panel.background = element_rect(fill = NA, color = NA),
  panel.border = element_rect(fill = NA, color = NA),
  panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
  panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
  axis.text.x = element_blank(),
  axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),
  axis.ticks = element_blank(),
  axis.title.y = element_text(size = 13, margin = margin(r = 10)),
  legend.title = element_text(size = 9),
    plot.caption = element_text(
    family = "Special Elite",
    size = 10,
    color = "grey70",
    face = "bold",
    hjust = .5,
    margin = margin(5, 0, 20, 0)
  ),
  plot.margin = margin(10, 25, 10, 25)
)

p <- 
  dat %>% 
  ggplot(aes(episode_mod, rating)) +
    geom_hline(
      data = tibble(y = 7:10),
      aes(yintercept = y),
      color = "grey82",
      size = .5
    )

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

p <- 
  p +
  geom_segment(
    aes(
      xend = episode_mod,
      yend = avg, 
      color = season
    )
  )

p <- 
  p + 
  geom_segment(
    aes(
      xend = episode_mod,
      yend = avg, 
      color = season, 
      color = after_scale(colorspace::lighten(color,.2))
    )
  )

Warning: Duplicated aesthetics after name standardisation: colour

p <- 
  p +
  geom_line(
    data = dat_lines,
    aes(
      x_group,
      y,
      color = season
    ),
    size = 2.5
  ) + 
  geom_point(aes(size = 2, 
                 color = season))

p + 
  labs(x = "", 
       y = "") +
  geom_label(
    aes(
      mid,
      10.12,
      label = glue::glue(" Season {season} "),
      color = season
    ),
    fill = NA,
    fontface = "bold",
    label.padding = unit(.2,"lines"),
    label.r = unit(.25,"lines")
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(expand = c(.015,.015)) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    expand = c(.03,.03),
    limits = c(6.5,10.2),
    breaks = seq(6.5,10, by = .5),
    sec.axis = dup_axis(name = NULL)
  ) +
    scale_color_manual(
      values = c("#486090", "#D7BFA6", "#6078A8", "#9CCCCC", "#7890A8", 
                 "#C7B0C1", "#B5C9C9", "#90A8C0", "#A8A890"),
      guide = FALSE # don't show guide for the color scale.
    ) +
    scale_size_binned(name = "Votes per Episode", range = c(.3, 3)) +
  guides(
      size = guide_bins(
        show.limits = TRUE,
        direction = "horizontal",
        title.position = "top",
        title.hjust = .5
      )
    ) 

Warning: The `guide` argument in `scale_*()` cannot be `FALSE`. This was deprecated in
ggplot2 3.3.4.
ℹ Please use "none" instead.

title: 3  Chapter 1: Reading and Writing an APA Style Paper
text:
R Course Learning Outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

Install and set up R and RStudio, and be familiar with R syntax and basic data types.
Import and export data in various formats, and clean and wrangle data as needed.
Calculate descriptive statistics, create data visualizations, and generate summary statistics using R.
Conduct hypothesis tests and interpret statistical output for t-tests, ANOVA, correlation, and regression analyses.
Apply advanced statistical techniques such as factor analysis, reliability and validity analysis, and Bayesian statistics.
Analyze psychological data using R and communicate statistical results effectively in research reports and presentations.
Develop skills in problem-solving, critical thinking, and data analysis that are transferable to other fields.
